Higgins, Rob J.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Pitfall trapping revealed that the European fire ant,<jats:italic>Myrmica rubra</jats:italic>(Linnaeus) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), represents an unusual example of a temperate invasive ant species. In British Columbia, Canada,<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>populations are associated with a decreased incidence and abundance of other ant species in three different plant communities when compared with<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>-free control areas.<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>represented more than 99.99% of the total ant fauna caught in the infested areas, and the numbers of<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>captured in the plant communities ranged from over 10 times to over 1300 times the total number of all ants collected in corresponding<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>-free areas. Total numbers of some taxa of insects and non-insect arthropods, including those likely to be competitors or prey of<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>, were reduced where the invasive species was present. Biodiversity indexes for the overall suite of captured arthropod species were lower where<jats:italic>M. rubra</jats:italic>was present in all three plant communities but most of this decrease can be attributed to the difference in the ant fauna.</jats:p>
